Privacy-Aware Compression for Federated Learning Through
Numerical Mechanism Design

Chuan Guo â€ƒâ€ƒ Kamalika Chaudhuri â€ƒâ€ƒ Pierre Stock â€ƒâ€ƒ Mike Rabbat
Abstract

In private federated learning (FL), a server aggregates differentially private updates from a large number of clients in order to train a machine learning model. The main challenge in this setting is balancing privacy with both classification accuracy of the learnt model as well as the number of bits communicated between the clients and server. Prior work has achieved a good trade-off by designing a privacy-aware compression mechanism, called the minimum variance unbiased (MVU) mechanism, that numerically solves an optimization problem to determine the parameters of the mechanism. This paper builds upon it by introducing a new interpolation procedure in the numerical design process that allows for a far more efficient privacy analysis. The result is the new Interpolated MVU mechanism that is more scalable, has a better privacy-utility trade-off, and provides SOTA results on communication-efficient private FL on a variety of datasets.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL; McMahan etÂ al. (2017)) is a distributed solution for machine learning on sensitive data and has been the topic of much recent interest. In federated learning, raw client data resides entirely on the client device, and a server coordinates the collaborative training of a global model through transmissions of model updates. Direct transmission of raw updates (pseudo-gradients) can lead to privacy leaksÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Zhao etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021; Jeon etÂ al., 2021), and an effective method is to use a rigorous privacy solution such as differential privacy (DP; Dwork etÂ al. (2006)) to transmit privacy-preserving updates. Since federated learning typically involves low-bandwidth clients, a requirement for success is that the amount of communication between the clients and server should be relatively low. Thus a major challenge in this space is ensuring a good privacy-accuracy-communication trade-offâ€”in other words, balancing the predictive accuracy of the model learnt with the privacy parameter as well as the number of bits transmitted between the client and server.

Previous work in this areaÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021; Triastcyn etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2022b) abstracted this problem as privacy-aware compression for distributed mean estimation (DME). Here, the goal is to design a DP mechanism whose output recovers the input in expectation (i.e., is unbiased) and can be represented using a small number of bits. In particular, recent workÂ (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022) introduces the minimum variance unbiased (MVU) mechanism, which solves a numerical optimization problem to find the parameters of a mechanism that ensures unbiasedness, privacy and communication efficiency while minimizing the variance of the output. They also experimentally demonstrate that, for a given bit budget, this can lead to better privacy-utility trade-offs than many other methods that independently privatize and then compress.

Unfortunately, a problem with the MVU mechanism (and many other privacy-aware compression mechanisms such as Kairouz etÂ al. (2021a); Agarwal etÂ al. (2021)) is that it does not scale well to high-dimensional vectors. This is a crucial drawback for its application to private FL since model updates are often high-dimensional. A major underlying reason for this drawback is the MVU mechanismâ€™s insistence on unbiasedness. This is achieved using randomized dithering to ensure that the mechanism is unbiased for all continuous-valued inputs, but leads to inefficiencies in the mechanismâ€™s computation and privacy accounting for high-dimensional vectors. Importantly, this drawback is in fact superficial since unbiasedness is not required for FL, and prior work has shown that even crude compressors such as SignSGDÂ (Jin etÂ al., 2020) can perform remarkably well.

In this work, we propose the interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism, which extends MVU using an interpolation procedure that relaxes the unbiasedness assumption. By its discrete nature, the MVU mechanism can be viewed as sampling from a particular categorical distribution, and hence can be expressed in exponential family form. The proposed I-MVU mechanism handles continuous-valued inputs by interpolating the natural exponential family parameters, rather than directly interpolating the probabilities as in dithering. We introduce a new analysis technique, and by further exploiting special properties of the exponential family, we obtain a tight numerical privacy analysis for the vector extension under both L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} geometry.

Experimentally, we find that under both client-level and sample-level DP settings and across various benchmark datasets, the I-MVU mechanism provides a better privacy-utility trade-off than SignSGDÂ (Jin etÂ al., 2020) and MVUÂ (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022) at an extremely low communication budget of one bit per gradient dimension. Moreover, I-MVU achieves close to the same performance as the standard non-compressed Laplace and Gaussian mechanismsÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016) for similar levels of (Ïµ,Î´)\epsilon,\delta)-DP, leading to new state-of-the-art results for private communication-efficient FL.

Differential privacyÂ (Dwork etÂ al., 2006) is a cryptographically-motivated definition of privacy that has emerged as the gold standard in privacy-preserving data analysis, and provides rigorous guarantees of privacy leakage induced by a mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M}.

Enforcing this property ensures that a single personâ€™s data does not substantially change the probability of any event that comes out of using the output of the mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M}.

2.2 Federated Learning with Differential Privacy

Federated learning (FL)Â (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Kairouz etÂ al., 2021b) allows distributed training of ML models across multiple clients without centralized data storage. A server coordinates training by acquiring model updates from clients, aggregating them, and then transmitting an updated model back to the clients, and the process repeats until convergence. One promise of FL is data privacy since the updates are computed locally on each client using their own data, and hence no client data is ever explicitly transmitted to the server (or anyone else) throughout training.

In spite of this, a recent line of work showed that it is possible to reconstruct training samples from the model updates in a process called gradient inversionÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Zhao etÂ al., 2020). To truly preserve the privacy of training data in FL, differential privacy (DP; Dwork etÂ al. (2006) can be applied to the model updatesÂ (Geyer etÂ al., 2017) to provide provable guarantees against data reconstruction from the its outputÂ (Balle etÂ al., 2022; Guo etÂ al., 2022; Stock etÂ al., 2022). To apply DP to FL training, given a DP mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and a client update ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, the client instead sends â„³â€‹(ğ±)â„³ğ±\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) to the server. For a given round, the clientâ€™s privacy leakage can be computed in terms of local DP if the privatized update â„³â€‹(ğ±)â„³ğ±\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) is revealed to the server, or global DP if secure aggregationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) is applied to aggregate the privatized updates before revealing it to the server. The total privacy leakage throughout training can then be computed via RDP composition and conversion to (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP via EquationÂ 1.

2.3 MVU Mechanism

Privacy-aware compression.

Since model updates in FL are high-dimensional vectors of size equal to the number of model parameters, it is also important in practice to compress these updates for communication efficiency. Prior work studied this privacy-aware compression problem under the abstraction of distributed mean estimation (DME), where clients aim to compute the mean of a set of vectors in a distributed fashion under communication constraint. Formally stated, consider the problem of transmitting a vector ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} differentially privately using at most bâ€‹dğ‘ğ‘‘bd bits, with bâ‰¥1ğ‘1b\geq 1 small enough so that the entire vector ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} can be transmitted efficiently. One can reduce this problem to a scalar one by considering how to privately compress xâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥01x\in[0,1] using at most bğ‘b bits, and then scaling the vector ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} appropriately and applying the scalar mechanism coordinate-wise.

3 Interpolated MVU Mechanism

Motivation.

At a high level, distributed mean estimation in general and its application to FL have different considerations and requirements.

  1. 1.

    The unbiasedness requirement in DME is often unnecessary for FL, as the global model does not require a truly unbiased gradient in order to achieve high accuracy.

  2. 2.

    Model updates in FL are typically high-dimensional, which creates issues for the randomized dithering operation used in MVU and other privacy-aware compression mechanismsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021). For vectors ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, dithering increases â€–ğ±â€–1subscriptnormğ±1\|\mathbf{x}\|_{1} and â€–ğ±â€–2subscriptnormğ±2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2} significantly when dğ‘‘d is large, hence rejection sampling is needed to control the norm of ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} after dithering. This makes it computationally expensive to apply MVU and causing its privacy accounting to be pessimistic.

Interpolated MVU.

To address these issues, we propose a new interpolation scheme for extending the MVU mechanism to continuous-valued vector inputs. Our new scheme relaxes the unbiasedness requirement in MVU and makes it more suitable for FL use cases. Our first insight is that the categorical distribution used in MVU can be expressed in exponential family form as follows:

â„™â€‹(j|ğœ¼)=expâ¡(ğjâŠ¤â€‹ğœ¼âˆ’Aâ€‹(ğœ¼)),Aâ€‹(ğœ¼)=logâ¡(âˆ‘jexpâ¡(ğœ¼j)),formulae-sequenceâ„™conditionalğ‘—ğœ¼superscriptsubscriptğğ‘—topğœ¼ğ´ğœ¼ğ´ğœ¼subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ¼ğ‘—\mathbb{P}(j|\boldsymbol{\eta})=\exp(\mathbf{e}_{j}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\eta}-A(\boldsymbol{\eta})),\;A(\boldsymbol{\eta})=\log\left(\sum\nolimits_{j}\exp(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{j})\right), (3)

where ğjsubscriptğğ‘—\mathbf{e}_{j} is the jğ‘—j-th standard basis vector. Note that if ğ©âˆˆÎ”Boutâˆ’1ğ©superscriptÎ”subscriptğµout1\mathbf{p}\in\Delta^{B_{\text{out}}-1} then its natural parameter is ğœ¼=logâ¡ğ©ğœ¼ğ©\boldsymbol{\eta}=\log\mathbf{p}.

Given xâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥01x\in[0,1], say xâˆˆ[xi,xi+1]ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}] for some iğ‘–i, the interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism samples jâˆ¼â„™(â‹…|ğœ¼(x))j\sim\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)) according to EquationÂ 3 and outputs ajsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—a_{j} from the MVU output alphabet, where

and Î”=1/(Binâˆ’1)Î”1subscriptğµin1\Delta=1/(B_{\text{in}}-1). In other words, instead of linearly interpolating between ğ©isubscriptğ©ğ‘–\mathbf{p}_{i} and ğ©i+1subscriptğ©ğ‘–1\mathbf{p}_{i+1} as in EquationÂ 2 for the MVU mechanism, we linearly interpolate between the natural parameters ğœ¼isubscriptğœ¼ğ‘–\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i} and ğœ¼i+1subscriptğœ¼ğ‘–1\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}.

Controlling bias.

For MVU, because the mechanism is designed so that it is unbiased at all grid points in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, it is easy to show via EquationÂ 2 and linearity of expectation that it is unbiased for all xâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥01x\in[0,1]. This is not true for I-MVU, and interpolating in the natural parameter space incurs some bias when xâˆ‰ğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\notin\mathcal{X}. However, by increasing the number of grid points BinsubscriptğµinB_{\text{in}}, we can reduce this bias to arbitrarily small with very few drawbacks.

FigureÂ 1 shows the expectation (top) and variance (bottom) of MVU and I-MVU for different values of Bin=2,4,8subscriptğµin248B_{\text{in}}=2,4,8. The mechanisms are constructed to output b=3ğ‘3b=3 bits with target L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-metric-DP Ïµ=5italic-Ïµ5\epsilon=5. For Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2, we see that ğ”¼â€‹[â„³â€‹(x)]=xğ”¼delimited-[]â„³ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{M}(x)]=x for all xâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥01x\in[0,1] for MVU, while the same does not hold for I-MVU. As we increase the number of grid points to Bin=4,8subscriptğµin48B_{\text{in}}=4,8, the expectation of I-MVU more closely matches that of MVU and the bias tends towards zero. In the bottom plots we show the variance of MVU and I-MVU for different xâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥01x\in[0,1] and compare it with that of the Laplace mechanism for the same value of Ïµ=5italic-Ïµ5\epsilon=5. Notably, for Bin=4,8subscriptğµin48B_{\text{in}}=4,8, MVU and I-MVU attain comparable variance to that of Laplace while communicating only b=3ğ‘3b=3 bits.

3.1 Extensions

Vector I-MVU.

We can extend scalar I-MVU to vector I-MVU by applying the scalar mechanism independently across the vector coordinates. As we will show in subsectionÂ 3.2, by utilizing special properties of exponential family distributions, we can more tightly analyze the privacy cost of I-MVU for L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}- and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors. In addition, because I-MVU does not need to use rejection sampling to control the gradient norm after randomized dithering, privatizing the input simply amounts to sampling a single categorical random variable per coordinate and is much more computationally efficient.

Input scaling. One way to extend I-MVU to arbitrary bounded ranges is to first scale the input to [0,1]01[0,1] and then apply the mechanism as usual. However, note that the interpolation scheme in EquationÂ 4 is in fact well-defined for any xâˆˆâ„ğ‘¥â„x\in\mathbb{R}, and hence the scaled input does not need to be strictly in the range [0,1]01[0,1]. We leverage this property by introducing a scaling factor Î²â‰¥0ğ›½0\beta\geq 0 as follows. For uâˆˆ[âˆ’C,C]ğ‘¢ğ¶ğ¶u\in[-C,C], the Î²ğ›½\beta-scaled I-MVU mechanism is defined as:

â„³Î²â€‹(u)=â„³â€‹(12+Î²â€‹u2â€‹C),subscriptâ„³ğ›½ğ‘¢â„³12ğ›½ğ‘¢2ğ¶\mathcal{M}_{\beta}(u)=\mathcal{M}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\beta u}{2C}\right),

where â„³â„³\mathcal{M} is the plain I-MVU mechanism. Note that this scaling effectively ensures that the input to â„³â„³\mathcal{M} is in the range [(1âˆ’Î²)/2,(1+Î²)/2]1ğ›½21ğ›½2\left[(1-\beta)/2,(1+\beta)/2\right], with Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 corresponding to scaling the input to [0,1]01[0,1]. For vectors ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} with â€–ğ®â€–2â‰¤Csubscriptnormğ®2ğ¶\|\mathbf{u}\|_{2}\leq C, the Î²ğ›½\beta-scaled input ğ±=12+Î²â€‹ğ®2â€‹Cğ±12ğ›½ğ®2ğ¶\mathbf{x}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\beta\mathbf{u}}{2C} satisfies â€–ğ±â€–2â‰¤Î²/2subscriptnormğ±2ğ›½2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\leq\beta/2.

One advantage for using Î²ğ›½\beta-scaling is that if the distribution of uğ‘¢u is highly concentrated near zero, then scaling with Î²>1ğ›½1\beta>1 ensures that the input to â„³â„³\mathcal{M} is more spread out in the range [0,1]01[0,1]. Because the MVU mechanism is designed to minimize the average variance across the range [0,1]01[0,1] (property 3), doing so allows us to better utilize its minimum variance property. For L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}- and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} this is especially true, where the distribution of coordinates of ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} is likely concentrated near zero, hence Î²ğ›½\beta-scaling with a large Î²ğ›½\beta is essential for achieving good performance.

3.2 Privacy Analysis

We analyze privacy leakage of the I-MVU mechanism in terms of both pure DP and RÃ©nyi DPÂ (Mironov, 2017). We first present a general analysis for the I-MVU mechanism with any Binâ‰¥1subscriptğµin1B_{\text{in}}\geq 1 applied to L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded vectors in TheoremÂ 1. Then we give a more specialized analysis for I-MVU with Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2 applied to L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors in TheoremÂ 2. Proofs of theorems and lemmas are given in Appendix A.

L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded vector analysis.

Our strategy is to first analyze the scalar mechanism and express its max divergence for two differing inputs xğ‘¥x and xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime} as a function of |xâ€²âˆ’x|superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¥|x^{\prime}-x| (Lemma 1). Then, by independently applying the mechanism across coordinates, we can sum the max divergence across coordinates and upper bound the total DP Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon as a function of â€–ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ±â€–1subscriptnormsuperscriptğ±â€²ğ±1\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1} (Theorem 1).

Lemma 1.

Suppose x,xâ€²âˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²01x,x^{\prime}\in[0,1] and the MVU mechanism satisfies Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-metric-DP. Let Ïµâ€²=(Binâˆ’1)Ã—(maxiâ¡maxÎ¾âˆˆ[xi,xi+1]â¡|Ïƒâ€‹(ğ›ˆâ€‹(Î¾))âŠ¤â€‹(ğ›ˆi+1âˆ’ğ›ˆi)|)superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²subscriptğµin1subscriptğ‘–subscriptğœ‰subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğœsuperscriptğ›ˆğœ‰topsubscriptğ›ˆğ‘–1subscriptğ›ˆğ‘–\epsilon^{\prime}=(B_{\text{in}}-1)\times(\max_{i}\max_{\xi\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}]}|\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(\xi))^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}-\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i})|). Then:

Theorem 1.

Let Ïµâ€²superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²\epsilon^{\prime} be the constant from Lemma 1. Suppose the MVU mechanism is Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-metric-DP and that ğ±,ğ±â€²âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptğ±â€²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfy â€–ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ±â€–1â‰¤Csubscriptnormsuperscriptğ±â€²ğ±1ğ¶\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{1}\leq C, then the I-MVU mechanism is (Ïµ+Ïµâ€²)â€‹Citalic-Ïµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²ğ¶(\epsilon+\epsilon^{\prime})C-DP.

The constant Ïµâ€²superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²\epsilon^{\prime} can be computed numerically by maximizing the function hâ€‹(Î¾)=|Ïƒâ€‹(ğœ¼â€‹(Î¾))âŠ¤â€‹(ğœ¼i+1âˆ’ğœ¼i)|â„ğœ‰ğœsuperscriptğœ¼ğœ‰topsubscriptğœ¼ğ‘–1subscriptğœ¼ğ‘–h(\xi)=|\sigma(\boldsymbol{\eta}(\xi))^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i+1}-\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i})| over the range Î¾âˆˆ[xi,xi+1]ğœ‰subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1\xi\in[x_{i},x_{i+1}] for every iğ‘–i.

L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vector analysis.

Our privacy analysis for L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors follows a similar strategy, but instead depends on a measure of information known as Fisher information, which we define below for completeness. Intuitively, Fisher information measures the curvature of the RÃ©nyi divergence, i.e., the rate of change of divergence with respect to input xğ‘¥x.

Definition 2.

Let fğ‘“f be the density function of a distribution parameterized by xâˆˆâ„ğ‘¥â„x\in\mathbb{R}. The Fisher information of xğ‘¥x contained in a sample Zâˆ¼f(â‹…|x)Z\sim f(\cdot|x) is:

â„Zâ€‹(x):=ğ”¼Zâ€‹[(ddâ€‹xâ€‹logâ¡fâ€‹(Z|x))2].assignsubscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼ğ‘delimited-[]superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘“conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥2\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x):=\mathbb{E}_{Z}\left[\left(\frac{d}{dx}\log f(Z|x)\right)^{2}\right]. (5)

In our setting, the distribution â„™(â‹…|ğœ¼(x))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)) is defined by the private data xğ‘¥x, and Fisher information measures how much information is revealed about xğ‘¥x through a sample jâˆ¼â„™(â‹…|ğœ¼(x))j\sim\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x)). It is noteworthy that such a reasoning has also been used to define Fisher information as a privacy metricÂ (Hannun etÂ al., 2021).

For Fisher information to be well-defined, it is necessary that the distribution has a differentiable log density function. For the I-MVU interpolation scheme this is only true if Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2; otherwise, the log density may be non-differentiable when transitioning from an interval [xiâˆ’1,xi]subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–[x_{i-1},x_{i}] to [xi,xi+1]subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1[x_{i},x_{i+1}]. Thus, Lemma 2 and Theorem 2 below are specialized to Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2, which we find is sufficient for most FL applications with L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors.

Let Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2 and let M=supxâˆˆâ„â„Zâ€‹(x)ğ‘€subscriptsupremumğ‘¥â„subscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘¥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) be an upper bound on the Fisher information of the mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M}. Then for any x1,x2âˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â„x_{1},x_{2}\in\mathbb{R}:

Applying Lemma 2 in a similar manner as in the L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded case by summing the RÃ©nyi divergence across coordinates as a function of â€–ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ±â€–22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ±â€²ğ±22\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2} yields Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Let Bin=2subscriptğµin2B_{\text{in}}=2 and let Mğ‘€M be the Fisher information constant from Lemma 2. Suppose that ğ±1,ğ±2âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ±1subscriptğ±2superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfy â€–ğ±2âˆ’ğ±1â€–2â‰¤Csubscriptnormsubscriptğ±2subscriptğ±12ğ¶\|\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\|_{2}\leq C. Proof sketch. We first derive the Taylor series expression for the RÃ©nyi divergence between â„™(â‹…|ğœ¼(x1))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{1})) and â„™(â‹…|ğœ¼(x2))\mathbb{P}(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\eta}(x_{2})). The coefficient for the second-order term is given by the Fisher information â„Zâ€‹(x1)subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x_{1})Â (Haussler & Opper, 1997), and thus we give a numerical method to compute M=supxâˆˆâ„â„Zâ€‹(x)ğ‘€subscriptsupremumğ‘¥â„subscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘¥M=\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\mathcal{I}_{Z}(x) in Appendix B and use it in EquationÂ 6 to bound the RDP Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

4 Experiments

We evaluate the I-MVU mechanism for federated learning under the local DP setting, i.e., clients transmit the privately compressed model update â„³â€‹(ğ±)â„³ğ±\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{x}) to the server before aggregation. We consider two different notions of adjacency for DP: client-level, where adjacency is defined as removal of any client, and sample-level, where adjacency is defined as removal of a single sample at one client.

Baselines.

We compare I-MVU with several privacy-aware compression mechanisms that have been proposed for private FL training:

  1. 1.

    MVU mechanismÂ (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022) for L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  2. 2.

    Skellam mechanismÂ (Agarwal etÂ al., 2021), which discretizes the input using randomized dithering and adds noise from the Skellam distribution to achieve privacy-aware compression of L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  3. 3.

    SignSGDÂ (Jin etÂ al., 2020) is a strong simple baseline that first applies a non-compressed DP mechanism to the gradient and then transmits its sign coordinate-wise. Since it operates as a post-processing step on top of a non-compressed DP mechanism, it inherits the privacy guarantee of the non-compressed mechanism while only outputting one bit per parameter. We evaluate SignSGD with both Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms for L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded client updates.

  4. 4.

    Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms serve as the non-compressed baselines for L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded client updates. We transmit the private updates using floating point with 32 bits per parameter.

A good privacy-aware compression mechanism should achieve a desirable privacy-utility trade-off (i.e., high test accuracy with low DP Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) while transmitting the client updates in a communication-efficient manner. Since our application domain is FL, we did not consider many generic DP distributed mean estimation mechanisms such as PrivUnitÂ (Bhowmick etÂ al., 2018) and Poisson binomial mechanismÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2022b). These mechanisms are designed primarily for privately compressing low-dimensional vectors in an unbiased manner; in contrast, model updates in FL are high-dimensional L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors and do not need to be unbiased.

4.1 Client-level DP

We first evaluate under the client-level DP setting on MNIST and CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). Here, the privacy analysis guarantees that the learning algorithm is differentially private with respect to the removal of any client. We divide the training set among the clients with client sample size 1. Each client performs a single local gradient update in every FL round. This setting is equivalent to DP-SGD trainingÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016) but with the Gaussian mechanism replaced by a communication-efficient private mechanism.

Training details. Following (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022), we train a linear model on top of ScatterNet featuresÂ (Tramer & Boneh, 2020). This training recipe remains highly competitive under the central DP setting for MNIST and CIFAR-10 without leveraging any public data, hence we adopt it for FL training under local DP. Following Abadi etÂ al. (2016), we apply L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} gradient norm clipping to control the gradient sensitivity and then apply a privacy-aware compression mechanism to transmit the clipped gradient privately. We perform a grid search over hyperparameters such as number of update rounds, step size, gradient norm clip, and mechanism parameters Ïƒğœ\sigma (for Gaussian and SignSGD) and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (for MVU and I-MVU); see AppendixÂ C for details.

Result for L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded client updates. We first consider the more common approach of L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-norm clipping. Figure 2 shows the privacy vs.Â test accuracy curve on MNIST (left) and CIFAR-10 (right). Privacy is measured in terms of (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP at Î´=10âˆ’5ğ›¿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}. For each hyperparameter setting, we compute the average test accuracy over five training runs to produce a single Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy pair, and plot the Pareto frontier as a dotted line. The yellow line corresponds to the standard Gaussian mechanism without compression, which attains the best test accuracy at any given privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Both SignSGD and MVU are competitive, achieving close to the same level of accuracy as the Gaussian mechanism, but a non-negligible gap remains, especially on CIFAR-10. In contrast, I-MVU attains nearly the same performance as the Gaussian mechanism at all values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon on both MNIST and CIFAR-10. Since MVU and I-MVU are near-identical mechanisms, we argue that the performance gain comes primarily from the tight privacy analysis for L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} geometry using Fisher information (Section 3.2).

In Figure 3 we repeat the experiment with an ImageNet pre-trained WideResNet-28-10Â (Zagoruyko & Komodakis, 2016) model. The model is pre-trained on down-scaled 32Ã—32323232\times 32 resolution ImageNetÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2009) samples and then finetuned on CIFAR-10 using either the Gaussian mechanism, signSGD or I-MVU. We did not apply the MVU or Skellam mechanisms because the dithering operation is prohibitively expensive on such a large model. We observe a similar result where I-MVU matches the performance of the Gaussian mechanism across the board.

Result for L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded client updates. For completeness, we also show the result for compressing updates with L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-norm clipping. This approach is uncommon in private FL training as the noise variance is much larger, but can provide an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP guarantee as opposed to (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP with L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-norm clipping. Figure 4 shows the privacy (in terms of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP) vs.Â test accuracy Pareto frontier curve on MNIST (left) and CIFAR-10 (right). It can be seen that I-MVU with b=4ğ‘4b=4 attains almost the same privacy-utility trade-off as the non-compressed Laplace mechanism, while I-MVU with lower bğ‘b attain a worse trade-off. Surprisingly, SignSGD outperforms both Laplace and I-MVU with a communication budget of b=1ğ‘1b=1. We suspect this is due to the inherent variance reduction effect of sign compression and that FL training does not require the gradient to be unbiased.

4.2 Sample-level DP

Next, we evaluate under the sample-level DP setting on the FEMNIST datasetÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018) for classifying written characters into 62 distinct classes. Privacy analysis guarantees that the learning algorithm is differentially private with respect to the removal of any training sample from a client. The dataset has a pre-defined train split with 3,50035003,500 clients, from which we randomly select 3,15031503,150 clients for training and the remaining 350350350 clients for testing. A set of 555 clients is selected in each training round. Each client performs full batch gradient descent for a single local gradient update to compute the update vector. The update vector is privatized using a communication-efficient private mechanism and transmitted to the server.

Training details. We train a simple 4-layer convolutional network with 46k parameters for classification. The model achieves 84%percent8484\% accuracy when trained non-privately with FL. The client optimizer is SGD with a learning rate of 0.10.10.1 and no momentum. The server implements FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) with a momentum of 0.90.90.9. We perform a grid search on the server learning rate, the clipping factor, the noise multiplier Ïƒğœ\sigma for Gaussian and SignSGD, noise scale Î¼ğœ‡\mu for Skellam, and the L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-metric DP Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and scale hyperparameters for I-MVU. The hyperparameter ranges are given in TablesÂ 5, 4 and 6 in the appendix. In particular, SignSGD uses a much lower server-side learning rates since the updates (in {Â±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}) have higher magnitude.

Result. We show the privacy-accuracy trade-off for FEMNIST in FigureÂ 5. The Pareto frontier represents the optimal privacy-accuracy trade-off. The DP privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is given at Î´=10âˆ’5ğ›¿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}. We observe that I-MVU (blue dashed line) performs better than SignSGD (silver dashed line) for the same communication budget of one bit per update coordinate across the entire range of considered privacy budgets Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Moreover, I-MVU performs on par with the non-compressed Gaussian baseline (yellow dashed line), where clients perform local DP-SGD without compressing model updates. I-MVU also outperforms the Skellam mechanism (green dashed line) using 16 times less bandwidth. Additionally, to demonstrate the performance of I-MVU across a wider bit range, we display the performance of the proposed method for various communication budgets in FigureÂ 6.

5 Related Work

Privacy-aware compression.

The problem of privacy-aware compression for distributed mean estimation (DME) has received much attention in recent years. Prior work proposed notable mechanisms such as PrivUnitÂ (Bhowmick etÂ al., 2018; Asi etÂ al., 2022), discrete GaussianÂ (Canonne etÂ al., 2020; Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a), SkellamÂ (Agarwal etÂ al., 2021), MVUÂ (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022) and othersÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2020; Girgis etÂ al., 2021; Shah etÂ al., 2022; Chen etÂ al., 2022b; Lang & Shlezinger, 2022) for computing the mean of a set of vectors under communication constraint. Feldman & Talwar (2021) provides a general procedure for converting a non-compressed mechanism to a compressed one that is computationally differentially private under the assumption that the pseudo-random generator in the privacy mechanism is hard to break.

There are also other approaches for privacy-aware compression in FL that do not rely on solving the DME problem. For example, Jin etÂ al. (2020) first showed that a simple post-processing of non-compressed mechanisms by taking the sign is a strong baseline that does not attain unbiasedness but works well in practice. Other mechanisms such as DP-RECÂ (Triastcyn etÂ al., 2021) have also leveraged special properties of FL to design more efficient privacy-aware compression schemes for transmitting model updates.

Non-private compression in FL.

Previous work has also studied non-private compression in FL, with a focus on characterizing how noise due to (lossy) compression impacts optimization dynamics. Methods have been proposed to only compress up-link (from client to server) messagesÂ (Basu etÂ al., 2019; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020; Albasyoni etÂ al., 2020; Haddadpour etÂ al., 2021; Mitra etÂ al., 2021; Sadiev etÂ al., 2022), as well as both up- and down-link messagesÂ (Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020; Condat etÂ al., 2022). Although none of these provides privacy, they do illustrate that federated training is possible with biased compression methods. Note that, in private FL, the downlink messages can be considered non-private, so only the uplink would need to make use of privacy-aware compression.

Mechanism design through optimization.

Classical DP mechanisms are mostly derived from simple parameterized distributions and whose privacy is analyzed mathematically. For more specialized applications such as FL where the requirements are complex, it is often helpful to design custom mechanisms by optimizing a certain objective under DP constraints. Geng etÂ al. (2015) proposed the staircase mechanism and showed that it is variance-optimal in the low-to-medium privacy regime for privatizing L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}-bounded vectors. Bhowmick etÂ al. (2018); Asi etÂ al. (2022) proposed the PrivUnit mechanism and its variant PrivUnitG that are variance-optimal for privatizing unit L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} vectors under a communication constraint. More similar to our work, Bordenabe etÂ al. (2014) designed an optimal mechanism for location privacy by numerically solving a linear program.

6 Conclusion

We proposed the Interpolated MVU (I-MVU) mechanism that drastically reduces the amount of uplink communication in cross-device FL while providing differential privacy guarantees. I-MVU can be readily applied to DP training of FL models with L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}- and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-bounded vectors, with performing matching that of the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms while communicating as few as one bit per parameter.

Limitations.

We discuss several limitations of I-MVU and suggest potential directions for future work.

1. The mechanism currently operates under the local DP setting, which does not leverage the power of secure aggregation to further reduce the privacy cost. Since I-MVU outputs samples from the categorical distribution, their sum forms a so-called Poisson multinomial distribution, whose properties need to be analyzed to understand the privacy cost of I-MVU under the central DP setting.

2. Our work focused on extending MVU through better interpolation and privacy analysis and did not modify the underlying mechanism design problem. Choices such as the set of grid points ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, variance objective, and DP constraint can be adapted to better leverage the structure of the new interpolation scheme.

3. Our scalar-to-vector extension of I-MVU can achieve at best a one bit per parameter compression rate. Compressing further to below one bit per parameter may be necessary for applications of FL to large-scale models. Combining I-MVU with recent work on sketching-based compressionÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2022a) can be a promising solution.

Appendix D Additional Results

The budget parameter bğ‘b controls how many bits the I-MVU mechanism outputs. We performed ablation study on bğ‘b to show that for the sample-level DP experiment in Section 4.2, I-MVU with b=1ğ‘1b=1 achieves nearly the same privacy-utility trade-off as with b=2,3,4ğ‘234b=2,3,4. Figure 6 shows the global modelâ€™s test accuracy vs. DP Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for the Gaussian mechanism and I-MVU with b=1,2,3,4ğ‘1234b=1,2,3,4. Evidently, increasing bğ‘b from 1 to 4 does not result in a significant increase in test accuracy for a fixed value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. This can be contrasted with the result in FigureÂ 4, where increasing bğ‘b from 1 to 4 does result in a significant boost in test accuracy.
